TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE , the GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested on the strength of a provisional arrest warrant issued by a duty magistrate in connection with a request for his extradition made by GPE . The request was relayed to GPE through ORG . The charge related to the applicant 's involvement in international drug trafficking in cannabis . The information laid before the magistrate by the Attorney General referred , inter alia , to the DATE United Nations Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances ( “ the LAW ” ) , to LAW concerning designated countries and Government Notice CARDINAL published in ORG of DATE which reproduced the text of the Convention to which GPE acceded on DATE . Attached to the request was a Red Notice issued by ORG bearing the applicant 's description and fingerprints as well as a certificate issued by the Prime Minister under subsection ( CARDINAL ) of section CARDINAL of the DATE LAW ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE , pursuant to section CARDINAL ) of LAW , the applicant was brought before the Magistrates ' Court acting as a court of criminal inquiry in connection with extradition proceedings . A defence counsel was appointed for him . The presiding magistrate was different from the one who issued the provisional arrest warrant . The applicant did not challenge the lawfulness of his arrest and the proceedings were adjourned until DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed a judicial act with ORG alleging that the provisional arrest warrant was unlawful because , inter alia , there were no bilateral extradition arrangements between GPE and GPE and ORG had not been incorporated into domestic law .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Prime Minister as the minister responsible for justice matters replied to the act . The Prime Minister rejected the applicant 's claim as frivolous and vexatious . He stressed that both GPE and GPE were parties to LAW even though the Convention had not been incorporated into domestic law . On the latter point , he noted that NORP law was already sufficiently equipped and adequate to implement GPE 's obligation under LAW .

CARDINAL . At its next sitting on DATE , the applicant 's lawyer pleaded that ORG did not have jurisdiction to hear the case for extradition , that the provisional arrest warrant was therefore unlawful and that the applicant should be released . The prosecution disputed the applicant 's reasoning . The case was adjourned to CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . At the further hearing on CARDINAL DATE the applicant again pleaded that the NORP courts lacked jurisdiction to examine the extradition request as there was no extradition treaty in force between GPE and GPE and that LAW , although signed by GPE , had not been duly ratified in accordance with NORP law .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG rejected the plea of lack of jurisdiction and declared that it had jurisdiction to hear the case . ORG took into account , in particular , the applicant 's argument according to which ORG had not been ratified as required by LAW . It observed , however , that the said LAW only provided for the ratification of certain treaties , indicated in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) . The applicant argued that LAW fell under LAW , which imposed the ratification of any treaty affecting or concerning the relationship of GPE with any multinational organisation , agency , association or similar body . ORG could not accept such an interpretation , on the ground that LAW was binding for the GPE which signed it , but not for ORG . Therefore , it could not give rise to a relationship between GPE and ORG . The Magistrates ' Court moreover observed that LAW authorised arrest with a view to extradition of any person accused of an offence in a “ designated foreign country ” . As GPE had been designated foreign country by LAW DATE , the applicant 's deprivation of liberty could not be regarded as unlawful .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed to ORG . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , ORG found that there was no right of appeal at that stage of the proceedings under NORP law and that an appeal was only possible when a person was subject to an order committing him to custody to await his removal . Furthermore , the applicant had filed his appeal out of time .

CARDINAL . On DATE , while the extradition proceedings were still pending , the applicant filed an application with ORG in its constitutional jurisdiction . He alleged that his case gave rise to violations of LAW ) and CARDINAL of ORG . The applicant based his claim on the words “ lawful arrest or detention ” of a person in connection with extradition proceedings . His main argument was that GPE had not duly ratified any international treaty giving the ORG “ legal authority ” to arrest him with a view to his extradition to GPE . As to his plea concerning LAW , the applicant stated that there was no possibility to have the legality of the detention for extradition examined before the case was decided and an appeal lodged .

CARDINAL . The First Hall of the Civil Court listed the case for hearing on DATE . However , the case had to be adjourned to CARDINAL DATE to enable the applicant 's lawyer to produce witness evidence .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , ORG , under whose order the applicant was kept in detention , continued to hear the case , in anticipation of obtaining the relevant evidence to support the extradition request from GPE . The court had a DATE time - limit in which to conclude the hearings and render its decision . This period could be extended by further periods of up to a maximum of DATE by the President of the Republic .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was discharged on the grounds that there was no evidence to justify his extradition to GPE . The Attorney General did not appeal against the decision . The applicant was ordered by the police , acting as ORG , to return to the GPE within TIME .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant 's application to FAC was still pending when the applicant 's case was being heard by ORG . However , on DATE the applicant had to leave GPE , having been refused permission to stay in GPE pending the examination of his application to FAC . On DATE the applicant 's lawyer , who had been instructed by the applicant to file the constitutional case , requested that the Commissioner of Police , as ORG , be ordered to allow the applicant to return to GPE for the hearing of the case which was pending before FAC .

CARDINAL . On DATE the First Hall of ORG ordered that a lawyer be appointed for the applicant . According to the applicant , under domestic law any voluntary assumption of this mandate by the lawyer who filed the application to ORG would imply that the person assuming it would be personally responsible to the Government of GPE for all costs and expenses incurred in the proceedings . The applicant had no relatives in GPE . Furthermore , the lawyer acting on his behalf could not assume the position of a “ party ” in the proceedings had he applied to act as his lawyer in addition to being his legal representative since this would have raised serious issues of professional ethics . The acceptance of a voluntary mandate would make the lawyer personally involved in the proceedings as if it were his own case .

CARDINAL . In the event , the applicant never gave a power of attorney to a legal representative in GPE to enable his claim to be dealt with by FAC . Furthermore , the applicant was never granted permission to enter GPE and the domestic court never ordered that permission be granted .

CARDINAL . On DATE the First Hall of ORG adjourned the case pending the applicant 's confirmation that he intended to issue a power of attorney to a legal representative for the purposes of the proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE , in the absence of the parties at the resumed hearing , ORG adjourned the case sine die . The applicant still could not enter the country to continue the proceedings in the NORP courts regarding the lawfulness of his detention .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant 's action was declared deserted and his case was struck off the list .
CARDINAL . In so far as relevant , LAW reads as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) A person arrested in pursuance of a warrant under LAW shall ( unless previously discharged under subsection ( CARDINAL ) of that section ) be brought as soon as practicable and in any case not later than TIME from his arrest before ORG ( GPE ) as a court of criminal inquiry ( in this LAW referred to as the court of committal ) which shall have for the purposes of the proceedings under this section the same powers , as nearly as may be , including power to remand in custody or on bail , as the said court has when sitting as aforesaid . ( ... ) .

( CARDINAL ) Where an authority to proceed has been issued in respect of the person arrested and the court of committal is satisfied , after hearing any evidence tendered in support of the request for the return of that person or on behalf of that person , that the offence to which the authority relates is an extraditable offence and it is further satisfied
( a ) where the person is accused of the offence , that the evidence would be sufficient to warrant his trial for that offence if it had been committed within the jurisdiction of ORG of GPE ;
( b ) where the person is alleged to be unlawfully at large after conviction of the offence , that he has been so convicted and appears to be so at large ,

the court shall , unless his committal is prohibited by any other provision of this LAW , commit him to custody to await his return thereunder ; but if the court is not so satisfied or if the committal of that person is so prohibited , the court shall discharge him from custody .

Provided that notwithstanding any order discharging him from custody such person shall remain in custody until the expiration of DATE from any such order and , where an appeal has been entered by the Attorney General , until the appeal is disposed of or abandoned , or the Attorney General consents to the release of such person ” .
CARDINAL . The Magistrates ' Court of GPE , acting as a court of criminal inquiry , gave on DATE the following decision in the case of The ORG v. PERSON :

“ Dr. PERSON [ the lawyer of the accused ] points out that the arrest is illegal since it does not conform with the necessary conditions laid out in Art . CARDINAL ) of ORG in view of the fact that even LAW lays down the circumstances in which a person can be brought under arrest before the ORG , but in the circumstances no one is entitled to once again formally arrest the person charged so as to initiate proceedings .
Having heard both parties as to whether the arrest is justified or not .
Having heard submissions by the parties regarding the case , in the circumstances the arrest is not justified and thus orders the release of the person charged ” .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Criminal Code provides for the remedy of habeas corpus . This provision reads as follows :

“ Any magistrate who , in a matter within his powers , fails or refuses to attend to a lawful complaint touching an unlawful detention , and any officer of ORG , who , on a similar complaint made to him , fails to prove that he reported the same to his superior authorities within TIME shall , on conviction , be liable to imprisonment for a term from DATE . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the police arrested PERSON for a breach of LAW . During his detention he became suspect of a serious offence concerning the public security of GPE . On DATE the applicant applied to the ORG requesting that he should be either charged or released . On DATE the ORG considered that it had the power under LAW ( currently section CARDINAL ) of LAW to attend to a lawful complaint touching on unlawful detention . It also found that the police had not brought Price before the Magistrates ' Court within TIME as required by CARDINAL ( currently section CARDINAL ) of LAW . As a result , the court ordered ORG 's release .

CARDINAL . On DATE the First Hall of the Civil Court ordered PERSON to be detained for TIME for contempt of court . The detainee appealed under section QUANTITY of LAW . The Attorney General , with reference to ORG having invoked section CARDINAL of LAW , requested ORG to order ORG and the Commissioner of Police to bring ORG before the ORG and order either of them to set him free at once . According to the Attorney General , ORG 's appeal had suspensive effect on the execution of the judgment and , as a result , his continued detention was illegal . ORG acceded to the Attorney General 's request .
CARDINAL . In a judgment given on DATE in the case of PERSON v. Attorney General , ORG decided as follows :
“ The applicant criticises the decision of the first Honourable Court on the use which could have been made of Article CARDINAL of LAW .
The applicant reasoned as follows : “ With all due respect this is an offence in itself , it is a punishment and not a remedy ” .
During oral submissions applicant 's counsel made reference to a similar comment made by ORG with regard to a case still pending before ORG [ application no CARDINAL/CARDINAL ] . ...

If CARDINAL delves more deeply into the practice of a country , one will note that history is different . CARDINAL three years ago , former Chief Justice PERSON was writing ... about the existence of Habeas Corpus in GPE and he traced its roots precisely on this . It is true that this remedy is not often used ... but from the fact that the remedy is not often made use of one can not infer that the remedy does not exist . In fact recently this remedy was resorted to in the cases of GPE ( arrest alleged to be illegal ) as well as in the ORG case ( contempt of court or the air conditioner case ) . ”
